title: Can we use a satellite for the Internet? - Quora

response.answer_text: It’s going to work in some places, but not in city centres. As the other answer says, you need a view of an equatorial geosynchronous satellite, and the towers in the cities get in the way. Out in the country with no large hills/mountains, then yup, it will work. Won’t be cheap, but if there’s nothing else available it’s worth considering. The near future satellite Internet from Elon Musk and so on, well, not yet. 60 satellites (57 active and usable) isn’t nearly enough. There’s a claim that by the end of this year you will be able to subscribe, but I haven’t seen serious commitment about delay, cost, handover issues or much of anything else really. It will certainly work at some point, but maybe not in a city centre without considerable expense on someone’s part - you still need visibility of a reasonable part of the sky to get a usable link.

Somewhat. You can receive the internet from satellites (the downlink) but sending data TO the internet requires a landline connection to a satellite uplink station. That REALLY slows your internet connection as you have to WAIT while your signal transits several servers to get to the uplink and then waits in a queu to be sent. Most of the internet today is sent over glass fiber lines around the world and doesn’t use satellites at all.
